questions: If my car is stolen, what case will it be in law?
If I am arrested without a warrant, is that legal?
If someone denies me a job because of my caste, is that allowed?
If the government takes my land for a project, can I stop it?
If my child is forced to work in a factory, is that legal?
If I am stopped from speaking at a protest, is that against my rights?
If a religious place stops me from entering because I'm a woman, is that constitutional?
If I change my religion, can the government stop me?
If the police torture someone in custody, what right is being violated?
If I'm denied admission to a public university because I'm from a backward community, can I do something?

answers.query: If my car is stolen, what case will it be in law?

evaluation.answer: Based on the policy context, which refers to the Constitution of India's Seventh Schedule, the theft of a car would fall under "Criminal law." This is because theft is considered an offence against laws, and matters concerning mechanically propelled vehicles, along with criminal law, are listed under the Concurrent List.

evaluation.answer: Based on the provided policy context from the Constitution of India, there is no explicit statement declaring an arrest without a warrant to be illegal. The document primarily outlines the rights of an arrested person, mandating that they must be produced before the nearest magistrate within 24 hours of arrest and cannot be detained beyond this period without a magistrate's authority. This framework focuses on regulating the legality of detention following an arrest, rather than pre-conditions for the initial arrest.

evaluation.answer: No, it is not allowed to deny someone a job solely on the grounds of their caste in matters of public employment. The Constitution of India ensures equality of opportunity for all citizens and prohibits discrimination based on caste in any employment or office under the State.

answers.query: If my child is forced to work in a factory, is that legal?

search_results.text:
THE CONSTITUTION OF INDIA
(Part III.—Fundamental Rights)
14
Right against Exploitation
23. Prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labour.—(1) 
Traffic in human beings and begar and other similar forms of forced labour are 
prohibited and any contravention of this provision shall be an offence 
punishable in accordance with law.
(2) Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from imposing 
compulsory service for public purposes, and in imposing such service the State 
shall not make any discrimination on grounds only of religion, race, caste or 
class or any of them. 
24. Prohibition of employment of children in factories, etc.—No child 
below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or 
mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment.
Right to Freedom of Religion
25. Freedom of conscience and free profession, practice and 
propagation of religion.—(1) Subject to public order, morality and health and 
to the other provisions of this Part, all

principles therein laid down are nevertheless fundamental in the governance of 
the country and it shall be the duty of the State to apply these principles in 
making laws.

evaluation.answer: No, it is illegal for a child to be forced to work in a factory. The Constitution explicitly prohibits forced labor for all individuals, and specifically bans the employment of any child below the age of fourteen years in factories or mines, or in any other hazardous employment.

evaluation.answer: The policy context, referencing the Fundamental Rights under the Constitution of India, indicates that the right to speak is not absolute. It can be subject to reasonable restrictions imposed by law in the interests of public order, decency, morality, or to prevent incitement to an offence. Therefore, being stopped from speaking at a protest may not be against your rights if such action is based on a law imposing reasonable restrictions for public order.

12. Definition.—In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, “the

and the Legislature of each of the States and all local or other authorities within

evaluation.answer: The Constitution of India, under Article 15(2), generally prohibits discrimination based on sex regarding access to places of public resort. Therefore, denying entry to a woman at a religious place solely due to her sex would typically be considered unconstitutional. However, religious denominations also possess the right to manage their own affairs in matters of religion, as per Article 26(b).

evaluation.answer: No, the Constitution of India grants all persons the fundamental right to freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion. This means the government generally cannot stop you from changing your religion. However, this right is subject to considerations of public order, morality, and health.

Right to Constitutional Remedies

enforcement of the rights conferred by this Part is guaranteed.

writs, including writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition,
quo warranto and certiorari,
whichever may be appropriate, for the

clauses (1) and (2), Parliament may by law empower any other court to exercise 
within the local limits of its jurisdiction all or any of the powers exercisable by 
the Supreme Court under clause (2).

otherwise provided for by this Constitution.

evaluation.answer: Yes, if you are denied admission to a public university because you are from a backward community, you can approach the National Commission for Backward Classes. This Commission is established to protect and ensure the welfare and socio-economic development of socially and educationally backward classes, and has the power to investigate complaints related to these matters.
